NORP In DATE the NORP welfare system introduced a new pension calculation , namely ORG ( calculation of pension by reference to contributions paid throughout a life - time and revalorisation factors ) as opposed to ORG ( based on the salaries applicable to employees in DATE of service ) . CARDINAL . In DATE the applicants instituted judicial proceedings to ascertain their right to the restitution of the contributions they had paid to the ORG and which had not been used to calculate their pensions . They contended that if LAW bis had to be interpreted as not implying the right for them to take back their contributions , it would be discriminatory vis - à - vis both a ) other ORG employees and/or b ) other employees in general who had previously been transferred and had been reimbursed the excess contributions . They requested the reimbursement of the relevant sums .
CARDINAL . By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG ( TAR ) declared the application inadmissible on formal and procedural grounds .

CARDINAL . On appeal , by a judgment delivered on DATE in the relevant registry of the plenary ( PERSON ) , ORG ( PERSON ) rejected the claims on the merits . It held that the contributions which had been paid to ORG but had not been used for pension calculation could validly be vested in the ORG . In the ambit of a welfare system based on the principle of solidarity , the circumstances that social benefits do not reflect the contributions paid did not amount to unjust enrichment of the entity receiving the contributions . Lastly , the restitution of contributions was an exceptional measure not regulated by uniform norms and only applicable to a certain category of people . In consequence , in the absence of any specific norm to that effect , the applicants did not have a right to the reimbursement of contributions paid in excess . Moreover , the applicants had accepted to take up new employment with the civil service and requested the joining of their contributory periods .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the plenary ( PERSON ) of ORG ( PERSON ) had held that it was possible to reimburse contributions in excess to civil servants . The same was reiterated again in DATE in analogous cases relating to the dissolution of ORG ( enti mutualistici ) , whose employees were transferred to another organ of the civil service .
